pageContext.claim: “We have lifted 4.3 million people off of food stamps.”
pageContext.analysis: Jobs were growing at about the same rate under President Obama, so Trump's astonishment is misplaced. The U.S. has added 4 million jobs since Trump took office. And 3.6 million people (not 4.3 million) have stopped receiving food stamps since February 2017, according to the latest data. But experts say the improvement in the economy may not be the only reason for the decline. Most states have either no longer qualifiy for or have declined to apply for waivers that allowed some adults to keep their benefits for longer periods of time without employment.Reports have also suggested immigrant families with citizen children have dropped out of the program, fearing the administration's immigration policies. Moreover, the number of people collecting benefits under the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, formerly called food stamps, has been declining since fiscal year 2013. It had spiked because of the Great Recession but began declining under Obama.
